==Japanese==
{{ja-kanjitab|南|蛮|人}}

===Etymology===
Compound of {{compound|lang=ja|sort=なんばんじん|南蛮|tr1=nanban|t1=southern barbarian|人|tr2=jin|t2=person}}.

Originally used to refer to the southern {{m|ja|夷|tr=ebisu|pos=non-Japanese ethnic groups living in the Japanese archipelago}}, later used to refer to westerners arriving in Japan from the south. In this later usage, ''nanbanjin'' first referred just to the [[Portuguese]] and [[Spanish]], while the Dutch were called {{m|ja|紅毛|tr=kōmō||red hair}}. Over time, this distinction became less important, and ''nanbanjin'' referred to westerners in general.<ref name="KDJ">{{R:Kokugo Dai Jiten}}</ref><ref name="DJR">{{R:Daijirin}}</ref>
